unit: Unit 9 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Slopes
title: Test Prep Course Benefits
question_text:
Suppose researchers want to know if a positive linear relationship exists between pre- and post-test scores on the test.
Twenty-five students are given the test as a pre-test. Then these $25\text{ subjects}$ are put into an extensive review course. After the review course, the subjects took the test once more.
A linear regression $T$-test is performed on
$$H_0: B = 0 \\ H_a: B>0$$
Define B as the true slope of the linear regression line when plotting pre-test vs. post-test scores.
If $p<0.01$, one could conclude

choices.text: We failed to find sufficient evidence the review course helped.
Students who do well on the pre-test tend to do better on the post-test.
Students who do well on the pre-test also tend to do well on the post-test.

solution:
All a linear regression T-test will examine whether there is a linear relationship between the two variables. In this situation, we hope to determine if a positive linear relationship exists.

However, all a positive linear relationship means is that students who do well on the pre-test tend to do well on the post-test, and students who do poorly on the pre-test tend to do poorly on the post-test.

A linear regression T-test does nothing to determine whether the course was effective.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'E'.
